csrd_phases.applicable_standards: European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS), adopted via Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2023/2772
csrd_phases.assurance_requirement: Limited assurance from first year of application; transition to reasonable assurance subject to Commission review
csrd_phases.filing_format: XHTML with iXBRL tagging per ESRS Digital Taxonomy; filed within the Management Report

phases.label: Large Public-Interest Entities already subject to NFRD

scope.company_type: Large Public-Interest Entities (PIEs) already in scope for the Non-Financial Reporting Directive (NFRD / Directive 2014/95/EU)
examples: Large EU credit institutions and insurance undertakings with >500 employees
Non-EU parent companies with EU-listed subsidiaries qualifying as PIEs with >500 employees

size_thresholds.description: Must meet at least 2 of the 3 criteria (and already exceed the 500-employee threshold as a PIE)

mandatory_cross_cutting: ESRS 2 - General Disclosures (fully mandatory, no materiality opt-out)
topical_esrs_subject_to_materiality: ESRS E3 - Water and Marine Resources
ESRS E5 - Resource Use and Circular Economy
ESRS S2 - Workers in the Value Chain

phases.eu_taxonomy_reporting: Required — turnover, capex, and opex KPIs across all six environmental objectives
phased_ins_and_reliefs: ESRS 1 allows a 1-year phase-in for certain Scope 3 GHG (category-level) disclosures
ESRS 1 allows a 1-year phase-in for certain ESRS S2, S3, S4 disclosures in year 1
Value chain data: 3-year phase-in permitted where data is not yet obtainable from value chain partners
phases.notes: Largest and most established EU companies; highest reporting maturity expected. Estimated ~50,000 companies EU-wide across all phases; approximately 2,000 already reported under NFRD and are Phase 1 in-scope.

phases.label: Other Large EU Companies (not previously subject to NFRD)

scope.company_type: Large companies incorporated in the EU that were not previously subject to NFRD, plus EU-regulated market-listed companies regardless of size (excluding listed SMEs, covered in Phase 3)
examples: Large private EU companies not previously classified as PIEs
Large subsidiaries of non-EU parent groups incorporated in the EU
All companies listed on EU-regulated markets (excluding SMEs)

size_thresholds.description: Must meet at least 2 of the 3 following criteria to qualify as 'large'
size_thresholds.note: Companies below these thresholds but listed on EU-regulated markets are in scope regardless (unless qualifying as listed SMEs under Phase 3)

topical_esrs_subject_to_materiality: ESRS E3 - Water and Marine Resources
ESRS E5 - Resource Use and Circular Economy
ESRS S2 - Workers in the Value Chain

phased_ins_and_reliefs: Same 1-year and 3-year phase-in reliefs available as for Phase 1 (applied relative to their own first reporting year)
phases.notes: Significantly expands the reporting population to an estimated further 10,000-15,000 EU companies. Many will be reporting ESG data formally for the first time.

phases.label: Listed SMEs and Small Non-Complex Credit Institutions / Captive (Re)Insurers

opt_out_available.opt_out_deadline: 2028 (reporting year) — a 2-year opt-out/exemption period is available until FY2028 data, reported in 2029
opt_out_available.condition: Company must disclose reason for not reporting and state when it intends to comply

scope.company_type: Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) listed on EU-regulated markets; small and non-complex credit institutions; captive insurance and reinsurance undertakings
examples: SMEs with shares or bonds listed on EU stock exchanges (not just MTFs/OTFs)
Small non-complex credit institutions as defined under CRR Article 4(1)(145)
Captive insurance undertakings as defined under Solvency II

size_thresholds.description: SME definition: meets at least 2 of the 3 following criteria
size_thresholds.note: Upper bound: companies exceed the large company threshold are captured in Phases 1 or 2 regardless of listing status

applicable_esrs.standard: ESRS LSME — Listed SME Voluntary Standard (simplified subset of full ESRS)
applicable_esrs.description: A proportionate, simplified set of disclosure requirements developed by EFRAG specifically for listed SMEs. Significantly reduced number of mandatory data points compared to full ESRS.
mandatory_disclosures: Simplified ESRS 2 equivalent — governance, strategy, material topics
Selected quantitative KPIs from ESRS E1 (GHG emissions, energy)
Selected social KPIs from ESRS S1 (workforce characteristics, H&S)
ESRS G1 simplified (anti-corruption policies, business conduct)
applicable_esrs.note: Full topical ESRS (E1-E5, S1-S4, G1) apply only if topics are material per the simplified DMA

phases.eu_taxonomy_reporting: Required where applicable; simplified KPI presentation permitted
phases.notes: Estimated 3,000-4,000 listed SMEs in scope across the EU. Non-listed SMEs are not directly in scope of CSRD but will face indirect reporting pressure from large company value chain disclosure requirements (particularly ESRS S2 and Scope 3 category 1/11 data requests).

phases.label: Non-EU (Third-Country) Parent Companies with Significant EU Presence
phases.governing_directive: CSRD Article 40a — inserting Article 29b into Accounting Directive

scope.company_type: Non-EU (third-country) parent companies that generate significant revenue within the EU via EU subsidiaries or branches, regardless of where the parent is incorporated
trigger_conditions: Net turnover generated in the EU exceeds €150,000,000 for each of the last 2 consecutive financial years
AND has at least one large EU subsidiary (meeting Phase 1/2 size thresholds) OR at least one EU branch with net turnover exceeding €40,000,000
examples: US, UK, or Asian multinationals with large EU operating subsidiaries
Non-EU financial groups with significant EU banking or insurance arms
Non-EU technology companies with EU revenue hubs

size_thresholds.subsidiary_threshold: At least one EU subsidiary qualifying as a large company (Phase 2 thresholds) OR one EU branch with net turnover > €40,000,000

applicable_esrs.standard: ESRS VSME or full ESRS — determined by structure
applicable_esrs.description: Non-EU parent companies must publish a group-level sustainability report covering EU operations. The Commission may adopt specific standards for third-country companies (ESRS equivalent for non-EU entities).
applicable_esrs.reporting_entity: The report may be filed at the level of the non-EU ultimate parent or at the level of the largest EU subsidiary, with cross-reference permitted
applicable_esrs.equivalence: If the non-EU parent already reports under a standard deemed equivalent by the EU Commission (e.g. if US SEC climate disclosure rules are recognised), that report may satisfy CSRD requirements
applicable_topics: ESRS E1 - Climate Change (Scope 1, 2, 3 GHG for EU operations)
ESRS S1 - Own Workforce (EU employees as minimum)
Other topical ESRS subject to materiality assessment of EU-nexus impacts

phases.eu_taxonomy_reporting: Required for EU-based economic activities of the group meeting taxonomy thresholds

interaction_with_other_frameworks.ISSB_IFRS_S1_S2: EU Commission monitoring equivalence; partial overlap on climate disclosures
interaction_with_other_frameworks.SEC_climate_rule: Significant overlap with Scope 1/2 disclosures; Scope 3 and social topics remain additional EU requirements
interaction_with_other_frameworks.UK_SDR: UK Sustainability Disclosure Requirements partially aligned; not yet deemed equivalent

phases.notes: Estimated 3,000-10,000 non-EU groups globally will fall in scope. This phase has the most significant compliance complexity as it requires non-EU companies to map their EU revenue, identify the correct reporting entity, and potentially produce an ESRS-aligned report separately from their home-country sustainability reporting.

indirect_scope.description: Non-listed SMEs and micro-enterprises are NOT directly subject to CSRD but will face indirect reporting pressure
indirect_scope.mechanism: Large companies in Phases 1-4 must disclose Scope 3 GHG emissions (ESRS E1-6) and value chain social data (ESRS S2). To comply, they will request ESG data from their suppliers, many of which are SMEs.
indirect_scope.voluntary_standard: EFRAG has developed the VSME Standard (Voluntary Sustainability Reporting Standard for SMEs) to help non-listed SMEs respond to these data requests in a proportionate and structured way

vsme_tiers.basic: Minimum dataset — ~20 data points covering fundamental environmental and social indicators
vsme_tiers.narrative: Extended narrative disclosures for SMEs wanting more comprehensive reporting
